0.title: Adult Dosing
0.mono:
• catumaxomab has centralized marketing authorization by the European Medicines Agency (EMA) for use in the European Union (EU)
  • Malignant ascites, EpCAM-positive, when standard therapy not available or feasible: 10 mcg on day 0, 20 mcg on day 3, 50 mcg on day 7, and 150 mcg on day 10 infused INTRAPERITONEALLY over at least 3 hours; at least 2 days must elapse before the next infusion, and the infusion interval may be prolonged based on tolerability; overall treatment period should be no greater than 20 days; premedicate with analgesic, antipyretic, or NSAID (European Medicines Agency-approved dosing)

1.title: Pediatric Dosing
1.mono: safety and efficacy not established in pediatric patients younger than 18 years

3.title: Indications
3.mono:
Non-FDA Labeled Indications
Malignant ascites, EpCAM-positive, when standard therapy not available or feasible

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono:
• hypersensitivity to catumaxomab or any component of the product
  • hypersensitivity to murine (rat or mouse) proteins

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• cytokine release-related symptoms (eg, dyspnea, fever, vomiting, and hypo- or hypertension) have been reported; premedication recommended
  • hemodynamic insufficiency, edema, hypovolemia, hypotension, acute renal impairment, or hypoproteinemia; assess and resolve prior to each infusion
  • hepatic impairment (severe), liver metastases greater than 70%, portal vein thrombosis or obstruction
  • infections, acute, or other factors interfering with the immune system; use not recommended
  • performance status, solid, defined as BMI greater than 17 (after fluid drainage) and Karnofsky Index greater than 60; required before administration
  • renal impairment, moderate or severe
  • systemic inflammatory response syndrome (ie, fever, tachycardia, tachypnea, and leukocytosis), often within 24 hours of infusion, has been reported; standard therapy or premedication recommended

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Gastrointestinal:Abdominal pain (43.7%), Diarrhea (10% or greater), Nausea (10% or greater), Vomiting (10% or greater)
  • Other:Fatigue (10% or greater), Fever (10% or greater), Shivering (10% or greater)
Serious
  • Dermatologic:Erythema induratum (0.1% to less than 1%)
  • Gastrointestinal:Gastrointestinal hemorrhage (0.1% to less than 1%)
  • Hematologic:Thrombocytopenia (0.1% to less than 1%)
  • Immunologic:Systemic inflammatory response syndrome (3.8%)
  • Renal:Acute renal failure (0.1% to less than 1%)
  • Respiratory:Pleural effusion (1% to less than 10%), Pulmonary embolism (0.1% to less than 1%)

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
• General Information
    intraperitoneal use only; do not administer as a bolus or by another route
  • Intraperitoneal
    • dilute and administer only with specific polypropylene syringes, polyethylene perfusion tubing, polycarbonate infusion valves, and polyurethane solution-coated catheters
    • drain ascites fluid via catheter until flow stops or symptom relief prior to each dose; infuse 500 mL sodium chloride prior to each dose to support antibody distribution
    • withdraw appropriate amount of NS with 50-mL syringe (air buffer of at least 3 mL will be left in syringe); insert catumaxomab prefilled syringe cannula through the 50-mL syringe and inject directly into NS reservoir; do not draw back plunger rod to rinse prefilled syringe; place cap on 50-mL syringe and shake gently
    • insert 50-mL syringe into the constant infusion pump system and infuse at a constant rate over at least 3 hours; consider a 6-hour infusion for the first dose, depending on patient health status
    • administer prepared solution immediately if possible; may be stored for up to 48 hours at 2 to 8 degrees C or 24 hours at 25 degrees C or less
    • leave intraperitoneal catheter in abdominal cavity for entire treatment period
